data.name: Patterns
data.value:
{ "version": 3, "value": [ { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978721\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://docs.microsoft.com/powerapps/maker/canvas-apps/performance-tips", "cat_patterndetails": "Formulas, Controls with Low/No Usage", "cat_patterndetailsid": "433509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

To enhance the performance and maintainability of your Power Apps, consider minimizing the use of variables and collections. Here are some tips to achieve this:

  1. Use Direct Data Source Operations: Instead of storing data in collections, perform operations directly on data sources whenever possible. This reduces memory usage and improves app responsiveness. User for Named formulas is also strongly encouraged.

  2. Use Context Variables Sparingly: Context variables are useful for passing values between screens, but overusing them can lead to complex and hard-to-maintain code. Opt for direct data binding and formulas where feasible.

  3. Adopt Component-Based Design: Break down your app into reusable components. This modular approach can reduce the need for global variables and collections, as each component can manage its own state.

", "cat_patterndescription": "

This pattern refers to any variables, assets, or controls that has been defined but is not being or rarely used anywhere within the app.

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-UnusedVariables" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"6920098\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/guidance/coding-guidelines/code-optimization#eliminate-n1-problem", "cat_patterndetails": "Excessive Database or API requests", "cat_patterndetailsid": "443509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "High", "cat_patternseverity": 764860003, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Consider using a local collection for the lookup used within the gallery provided the data fetched is of small size. Alternatively, building an API server side to flatten the response is a preferred approach but requires pro-code development. 
", "cat_patterndescription": "
\n

This pattern typically occurs using gallery control. When we trigger too many requests to servers as a result of each item in the gallery performing a lookup on a direct data source.

\n\n

 

\n\n\n
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-CheckForNplusOneCalls" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"6330665\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://docs.microsoft.com/powerapps/maker/canvas-apps/performance-tips", "cat_patterndetails": "Inefficient Data Retrieval", "cat_patterndetailsid": "463509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "High", "cat_patternseverity": 764860003, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Optimize data retrieval by avoiding inefficient use of functions. Instead of using First(Filter(...)) or Last(Search(...)), Consider using Lookup() function to optimize performance.

", "cat_patterndescription": "
\n

Using Filter() or Search() functions inside First() or Last() can be inefficient, especially with external data sources, as it requires processing the entire dataset in memory before selecting the first or last record. This can lead to performance issues, particularly with large datasets

\n
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-FormulaOptimization-FirstFilter" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978725\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Functionality", "cat_patterncategory": 764860006, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-copilot-studio/guidance/trigger-phrases-best-practices#1", "cat_patterndetails": "Duplicate Queries", "cat_patterndetailsid": "473509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "Ensure no overlapping trigger queries across topics.", "cat_patterndescription": "This pattern checks for overlapping trigger phrases between topics. If multiple topics have similar or identical phrases, it flags them to avoid conflicts in bot behavior.", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "BotPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860002, "cat_patternid": "bot-DuplicateQueries" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978726\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Functionality", "cat_patterncategory": 764860006, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-copilot-studio/guidance/trigger-phrases-best-practices#3", "cat_patterndetails": "Single Word Phrases", "cat_patterndetailsid": "493509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Ensure all trigger phrases have more than one word. Recommended trigger phrase length is 2-9 words.

", "cat_patterndescription": "

Single-word trigger phrases should be avoided. Having single-word trigger phrases increase the weigth for specific words in topic triggering and can introduce confusion between similar topics.

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "BotPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860002, "cat_patternid": "bot-SingleWordPhrases" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"6330669\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/guidance/coding-guidelines/code-optimization", "cat_patterndetails": "Nested API Calls", "cat_patterndetailsid": "4d3509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "", "cat_patterndescription": "
\n

This pattern checks for nested API calls within Filter() and LookUp() operations which can lead to performance issues and make code readability harder. Additionally  Making API calls inside loops or nested within other API calls can significantly degrade performance, leading to increased latency and potential throttling issues. This approach can also create unnecessary dependencies between calls, reducing scalability. E.g. SortByColumns(Filter(Product, Email = Office365Users.MyProfile().Mail, \u201cTitle\u201d, TextSearchBox1.Text in Title), Ascending)

\n
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-FormulaOptimization-NestedApiCalls" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"6330668\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Maintainability", "cat_patterncategory": 764860007, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/power-fx/formula-reuse-named-formulas", "cat_patterndetails": "Named Formulas", "cat_patterndetailsid": "513509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

", "cat_patterndescription": "

This pattern checks for the use of Named Formulas in your application.  

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-NamedFormulas" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978729\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/guidance/coding-guidelines/avoid-anti-patterns#avoid-nested-for-each-loops", "cat_patterndetails": "Avoid Nested For-Each Loops", "cat_patterndetailsid": "553509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
A more efficient implementation is to use OData Query Expansion where we only need to work with a single Apply-for-Each loop. This also reduces the total requests against Dataverse to just one RetrieveMultiple call. Use the Expand Query parameter to specify the lookup column name. We can also add ($select=\u2026) to reduce the number of columns returned from the related table. The filter rows parameter can be used to apply conditions on the lookup table\u2019s column.
 
", "cat_patterndescription": "

Nested \"For Each\" loops can be an expensive operation in Power Automate (and in many other programming contexts) due to their potential impact on performance and resource consumption.
 

  • Increased Execution Time: With nested loops, the number of iterations multiply.

 For example, if you have 2 loops, each with 10 iterations, the total number of iterations becomes 10 x 10 = 100. This can significantly increase the execution time of your flow, especially if the loops process large datasets or perform complex operations within each iteration.

  • Limits and Quotas: Power Automate imposes limits and quotas on various aspects of flow execution, such as the number of iterations allowed within a loop or the maximum execution time. Nested loops can quickly reach these limits, causing the flow to fail or be throttled, particularly if it operates on large datasets or runs frequently.


", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "FlowPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860001, "cat_patternid": "flow-NestedLoops" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978730\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Coding Standards", "cat_patterncategory": 764860001, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/guidance/coding-guidelines/use-consistent-naming-conventions", "cat_patterndetails": "Consistent Naming for Flow Components", "cat_patterndetailsid": "593509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Here are some guidelines to follow:\n
Note: There are recommendations and may change as per individual organization requirements.
\n\n
    \n\t
  1. Descriptive and Meaningful Names: Give meaningful names to your flows before saving. Additionally, choose names that accurately describe the purpose or function of each component. Avoid generic or ambiguous names that could lead to confusion. For example, instead of naming a trigger \"Trigger1,\" use a descriptive name like \"New Email Received\" to clearly indicate its purpose.
    2. \n
\n
\n\n
\n
    \n\t
  1. Use CamelCase or Underscores: Use CamelCase (capitalizing the first letter of each word except the first one) or underscores to separate words in your component names. This improves readability and makes it easier to distinguish between different parts of the name. For instance, you might name an action \"SendEmailNotification\" or \"send_email_notification\" for consistency.
    2. \n\t
  2. Prefixes or Tags: Consider using prefixes or tags to categorize components based on their type or functionality. For example, you could use prefixes like \"Trg_\" for triggers, \"Act_\" for actions, or \"Var_\" for variables. This helps quickly identify the role of each component within the flow.
    3. \n\t
  3. Consistency Across Flows: Maintain consistency in naming conventions across all your Power Automate flows to facilitate navigation and standardization. This ensures that team members can easily understand and work with different flows without having to decipher unique naming styles.
    4. \n\t
  4. Document Naming Conventions: Document your naming conventions in a style guide or documentation to ensure that all team members are aware of the standards to follow. This promotes uniformity and reduces the likelihood of inconsistencies or misunderstandings.
    5. \n\t
  5. Add Comments \u2013 Adding comments to the actions make it easy to understand the flow implementation logic.
    6. \n
\n
", "cat_patterndescription": "
Maintaining consistent naming conventions for the components within your Power Automate flows is crucial for ensuring clarity, organization, and ease of management. By adopting a standardized approach to naming, you can enhance collaboration among team members, simplify troubleshooting, and streamline the development and maintenance of your workflows.
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "FlowPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860001, "cat_patternid": "flow-NamingConventions" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978731\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Maintainability", "cat_patterncategory": 764860007, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/guidance/coding-guidelines/create-scopes", "cat_patterndetails": "Create Scopes", "cat_patterndetailsid": "5a3509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
 
  1. Grouping Actions: You can add multiple actions inside a scope. This is useful when you have a series of actions that are related to each other or need to be executed together.
  2. Organizing Your Flow: By using scopes, you can create a hierarchical structure within your flow. You can have nested scopes, where one scope contains another scope, allowing you to break down your workflow into smaller, more manageable sections.
\n
  1. Error Handling: Scopes are also helpful for error handling. You can set up scopes to catch and handle errors that occur within the actions they contain. This makes it easier to troubleshoot and fix issues in your workflow. Error handling has been discussed in more detail, here
  2. Visibility and Collapsibility: Scopes can be collapsed to hide their contents, making it easier to focus on other parts of your flow. This helps keep your workspace neat and organized, especially when working with large and complex flows.
  3. Avoid using flows for every single action: Not every action is required to be within a scope. Please be mindful of overusing scopes action if there is no need.
", "cat_patterndescription": "
As workflows get more complicated, it's essential to manage them well to handle problems, test them, and keep them working smoothly. A Scope is like a container that holds a bunch of actions together.
\nThis makes it easier to organize and see distinct parts of your workflow. So, when your workflow grows bigger and more complex, using the Scope tool can make it easier to keep things in order and fix any issues that come up.
\n\n
 
\n\n
\n\n
 
\n\n
 
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "FlowPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860001, "cat_patternid": "flow-ScopeUsage" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978732\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Maintainability", "cat_patterncategory": 764860007, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/guidance/coding-guidelines/create-reusable-code", "cat_patterndetails": "Create Reusable Code (Child flows)", "cat_patterndetailsid": "5e3509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Why Use Child Flows?
\n
  • Modularity: Child flows promote modularity, allowing you to build reusable components that can be easily plugged into different workflows. This not only streamlines development but also enhances maintainability.
  • Scalability: By breaking down your automation into smaller, more manageable pieces, you can scale your processes more effectively. Need to make changes or add functionality? With child flows, it's as simple as updating the individual components.
  • Granular Control: Child flows offer granular control over your automation logic. You can pass data between parent and child flows, enabling dynamic decision-making and personalized experiences.
  • Collaboration: In a team environment, child flows promote collaboration by allowing team members to work on separate components of a larger automation project simultaneously.
", "cat_patterndescription": "
Power Automate cloud flows can help automate complex solutions, however, they can grow excessively big and complex really quick making it difficult to navigate and maintain the flow. Instead of building a complex single automation solution, leverage child flows which can add complexity, depth and efficiency to these automation processes. They allow you to break down
complex processes into manageable chunks, making your flows more modular and easier to manage.
 
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "FlowPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860001, "cat_patternid": "flow-ActionCount" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978733\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/guidance/coding-guidelines/implement-parallel-execution", "cat_patterndetails": "Parallel Execution and Concurrency (within For each loop)", "cat_patterndetailsid": "603509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
A good rule of thumb is to parallelize only when actions take more than 5 seconds to execute. You can use parallel branches to achieve some of the following scenarios:
\n
Sending non-blocking approval requests (blog post)
\n
  • Creating \u201cQuorum\u201d based approvals (blog post)
  • Creating or updating records in multiple systems
  • Getting data from multiple sources and consolidating them in one
\n
Concurrency Control
Concurrency enables Parallel execution in For Each loop. By default, For each loop executes sequentially. Therefore, when processing large data, it may take a lot of time. If the items in loop are not required to run sequentially, concurrency enables X items to process at once. Currently users are allowed to see the degree of parallelism from 1 to 50.
Consider a scenario where 100 records need to be updated with status as Active, instead of updating one record after the other, Concurrency control enables up to 50 records to be updated simultaneously.
\n

", "cat_patterndescription": "
Power Automate supports parallel execution meaning flows can have two or more steps that run simultaneously, after which the workflow will only priced once all parallel steps have completed.
This enables flow to do more processing at the same time, specifically when the tasks are asynchronous.
\n
 
\n
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "FlowPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860001, "cat_patternid": "flow-Concurrency" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978734\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/guidance/coding-guidelines/use-data-operations#variables-vs-compose", "cat_patterndetails": "Static Variables/Unused variables", "cat_patterndetailsid": "623509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Compose are not update-able at run-time. It is useful for write-once, read-many type of usage. If we need to write or update in many places in the flow, variables will be much more appropriate. Similarly, using compose to create variables can also perform faster than initializing+ Declare variables.
\n
When working with a set of variables that are updated within the same logical blocks in the flow, you can use JSON variables instead of individual variables. This help reduces the number of actions in the flow.
\n

\n
 
\n
Consider the above: Instead of working with Var1 and Var2 as separate variables, we can use 1 Object Variable to manage both values.
 
\n
", "cat_patterndescription": "
Checks for variables which have been initialized but are never updated in the power automate flow using any of the variable actions. The values of the variables defined during initialization are referenced in the power automate. These variables can be replaced with Compose actions as they are executed faster and can be referenced.
\n\n
 
\n\n
 
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "FlowPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860001, "cat_patternid": "flow-StaticVariables" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978735\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/guidance/coding-guidelines/optimize-power-automate-triggers#set-trigger-conditions", "cat_patterndetails": "Optimize Power Automate Triggers", "cat_patterndetailsid": "633509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Here is the flow for above scenario without trigger conditions:
\n
\n
Here is the flow with trigger conditions:
 
\n
\n
Note: In Dataverse triggers, OData filter property also allows the trigger to fire only when the filter conditions are met.
\n
You can also specify the names of the columns on which the flow can trigger.
 
", "cat_patterndescription": "
A common issue for many users who work with Power Automate is that their flow runs whenever a new row or an existing row is modified in the data source. However, we only need the flow to execute when a specific condition is satisfied. Setting triggers correctly can enable your flow to run only when necessary.
\n
\nConsider a scenario where any user who submits an expense above $5000 need to get approved by their management. If the trigger conditions are not specified, the flow will run for every expense that is submitted and flow author will have to specify additional conditions to filter the expense greater than
\n$5000. With trigger conditions, the flow will only trigger when the expense is above $5000.
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "flow-TriggerCondition" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978737\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/guidance/coding-guidelines/work-with-relevant-data", "cat_patterndetails": "Data Retrieval Optimization", "cat_patterndetailsid": "643509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Use Advanced options like Select columns (only allowing flow to get data corresponding to column names specified in the query), Filter rows (to get data based on the Filter condition) and Row count (to only get specified number of rows)
\n
 
\n
\n
 
\n
 
\n
", "cat_patterndescription": "
In Power Automate, working with only relevant data is crucial for efficiency and accuracy in your automated workflows. 
\n\n
(If a flow has List Rows DV action and is missing any of the 3 parameters from Select columns($select),Filter Rows($filter) & Row Count($top) then it\u2019s a failure or if the flow has Get items action and is missing Filter Query($filter) or Top Count($top) parameter then also it\u2019s a failure.
\n\n
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "FlowPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860001, "cat_patternid": "flow-DataRetrievalParameters" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978738\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/guidance/coding-guidelines/avoid-anti-patterns#avoid-using-for-each-loop-to-update-large-numbers-of-records", "cat_patterndetails": "Create Update Inside Loop (Use BATCH operations for multiple updates)", "cat_patterndetailsid": "653509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
To address this, you can try following 2 approaches:
  • Create/Patch records to the data source in BATCH. Most of the connectors/services expose API services to post request in BATCH. You can group multiple operations into a single HTTP request using a batch operation. These operations are performed sequentially in the order they're specified. The order of the responses match the order of the requests in the batch operation.
  • Parallelism in For Each loop provides up to 50 records to be processed for the services which do not have capability to accept BATCH requests.
Refer to the following links of rest APIs from Sharepoint and Dataverse which shows how to make batch requests.
", "cat_patterndescription": "
Often users find using Power Automate to create/updated 1000s of records to the data source when a flow is triggered. Most user would end up using For Each loop which will go through each of these 1000s records, and push them to the data source sequentially causing latency and delays.
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "FlowPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860001, "cat_patternid": "flow-CreateUpdateInsideLoop" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978739\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/guidance/coding-guidelines/asychronous-flow-pattern", "cat_patterndetails": "Asynchronous flow pattern (Power Apps Response)", "cat_patterndetailsid": "693509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Use asynchronous flow pattern for long running flows. In such cases, setting Asynchronous response will allow flow to respond with a 202 to indicate the request has been accepted for processing. Additionally, A location header will be provided to retrieve the final state.
\n
", "cat_patterndescription": "
\n
Generally, if a flow is called from a parent flow or a Power App, it has to send a response back to the calling entity within 120 seconds. If the called flow fails to do that, then the calling entity will receive a timeout and will error out.
\n\n
 
\n\n
 
\n\n
\n\n
 
\n\n
 
\n
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "flow-PowerAppResponse" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978740\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/blog/power-apps/performance-considerations-with-powerapps/", "cat_patterndetails": "Asset Optimization", "cat_patterndetailsid": "6b3509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Ensure that all files do not exceed 300KB file size. Please consider compressing the listed files using optimized file formats (e.g., SVG for icons, WebP for images), and limiting media file sizes.

", "cat_patterndescription": "
\n

Large asset sizes, such as high-resolution images, oversized media files, and uncompressed resources, can significantly impact app performance, increasing load times and affecting responsiveness, especially on mobile devices. Review embedded asset compression/size optimization. Validate apps respect limitations related to media and audio asset sizes

\n
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-AssetOptimization" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978741\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Accessibility", "cat_patterncategory": 764860000, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://docs.microsoft.com/power-apps/maker/canvas-apps/accessible-apps", "cat_patterndetails": "Accessibility", "cat_patterndetailsid": "703509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "High", "cat_patternseverity": 764860003, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Review accessibility checker to address issues related to screen reader compatibility, keyboard navigation, sufficient color contrast, and alternative text for images. Notes: Alternate Text labels can reveal otherwise hidden media and context to users with disabilities. Use natural language text when naming screens to optimize results from screen readers.

", "cat_patterndescription": "
\n

Accessibility ensures that all users, including those with disabilities, can interact with and use the PowerApps application effectively. Please address the listed accessibility issues in failure reason.

\n
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-Accessibility" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978742\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": null, "cat_patterndetails": "Patch Formula Optimization", "cat_patterndetailsid": "723509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Ensure the second parameter is not using a LookUp() function. It is a best practice to use ThisItem whenever patching from a gallery or { id: userid }.
", "cat_patterndescription": "
Optimize Patch formulas by avoiding unnecessary LookUp() functions.
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-FormulaOptimization-Patch" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978743\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Functionality", "cat_patterncategory": 764860006, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/connection-references", "cat_patterndetails": "ConnectionReferences", "cat_patterndetailsid": "743509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Ensure all connection references are correctly configured and utilized.

", "cat_patterndescription": "
\n

Connection References allow flows to use environment-specific connections without hardcoding credentials, making deployments across environments (Dev, Test, Prod) more manageable. Missing connection references can lead to manual reconfiguration and potential security risks. Check if all connection references are used and properly configured.

\n\n

 

\n\n
 
\n
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "FlowPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860001, "cat_patternid": "flow-ConnectionReferences" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978744\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Functionality", "cat_patterncategory": 764860006, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2290320", "cat_patterndetails": "Unused Variables", "cat_patterndetailsid": "753509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "Remove any variables that are declared but not used.", "cat_patterndescription": "Check for unused variables in the flow.", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "FlowPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860001, "cat_patternid": "flow-UnusedVariables" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"6920054\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/blog/power-apps/app-checker-now-includes-performance-optimization-tips/", "cat_patterndetails": "App Settings flags", "cat_patterndetailsid": "763509dd-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Please consider turning on the appropriate app settings (
", "cat_patterndescription": "
Ensure that all necessary settings are enabled for optimal performance.
\n\n
 
\n\n
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-AppSettings" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978746\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Functionality", "cat_patterncategory": 764860006, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://docs.microsoft.com/powerapps/maker/canvas-apps/functions/function-iferror", "cat_patterndetails": "Error Handling", "cat_patterndetailsid": "dfe403e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Use IfError() and Notify() functions to catch errors and provide user-friendly messages. Implement logging mechanisms to track failures and improve debugging.
", "cat_patterndescription": "
Proper error handling ensures that unexpected issues, such as failed data operations or invalid inputs, are managed gracefully, preventing a poor user experience. It is best to use the IfError() function to manage data validation for Patch() commands and the OnSuccess/OnFail properties when submitting form data.
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-ErrorHandling" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978747\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Maintainability", "cat_patterncategory": 764860007, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": null, "cat_patterndetails": "Code Readability", "cat_patterndetailsid": "e4e403e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Avoid expressions or formulas that are very long as they will become hard to read. Examples include, but are not limited to nested If/Then/Else statements and nested operators such as OR or AND. Avoid repetitive code. 
\n
Use format text to enhance readability
", "cat_patterndescription": "

This patterns checks for long PowerFx formulas that are hard to read and spans multiple lines of code. 

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-CodeReadability" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978748\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": null, "cat_patterndetails": "Nested Filters", "cat_patterndetailsid": "f0e403e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Simplify nested filters to improve performance. Combine multiple conditions into a single Filter() or Search() call to optimize data retrieval. Where possible, apply filtering at the data source level (e.g., using delegation-friendly queries) to improve performance and reduce processing load in Power Apps.
// Inefficient (Nested Filters)
Filter(
    Filter(Orders, Status = \"Completed\"),
    Amount > 500
)
\n
// Optimized (Single Filter)
Filter(Orders, Status = \"Completed\" && Amount > 500)
\n

\u2714\ufe0f Use a single Filter() call with multiple conditions when possible.
\u2714\ufe0f Apply filtering before searching to reduce dataset size before running expensive operations.
\u2714\ufe0f Optimize for delegation when working with external data sources to ensure efficient querying.
", "cat_patterndescription": "Consider simplifying nested formulas with Search() and Filter() operations. Avoiding the nesting of these two together leads to a more compact/concise formula and performance improvement.", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-FormulaOptimization-NestedFilter" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978750\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "UX", "cat_patterncategory": 764860017, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powerapps/maker/canvas-apps/create-responsive-layout", "cat_patterndetails": "UX Layout", "cat_patterndetailsid": "f5e403e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Using layout containers can significantly enhance the design and functionality of your apps:

  1. Responsive Design: Layout containers are essential for creating responsive designs that adapt to different screen sizes and orientations. By using containers, you can ensure that your app looks great on any device, whether it's a desktop, tablet, or mobile phone

  2. Organized Structure: Containers help you organize your app's interface by grouping related controls together. This makes it easier to manage and maintain your app, especially as it grows in complexity

  3. Improved Accessibility: Containers aid screen reader users in understanding the structure of the app. They provide a logical grouping of controls, which can enhance the accessibility of your app

  4. Enhanced Performance: By reducing the number of individual layout calculations, containers can improve the performance of your app. This is particularly important for apps with complex interfaces and many controls

", "cat_patterndescription": "

This patterns checks for use of layout containers in your app determine if you are app is responsive.

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-UxLayout" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978751\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Functionality", "cat_patterncategory": 764860006, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/trigger-types", "cat_patterndetails": "Trigger Types", "cat_patterndetailsid": "fee403e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Ensure that the triggers are appropriate for the intended use of the flow.

", "cat_patterndescription": "

Validate the types of triggers used in the flow.

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "FlowPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860001, "cat_patternid": "flow-TriggerTypes" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978752\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Functionality", "cat_patterncategory": 764860006, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-copilot-studio/guidance/trigger-phrases-best-practices#2", "cat_patterndetails": "Trigger Phase Count", "cat_patterndetailsid": "00e503e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Ensure each topic has at least 5-10 trigger phrases.

", "cat_patterndescription": "

Topics should contain at least 5-10 trigger phrases to ensure that the agent can effectively respond to a wide variety of user inputs. More trigger phrases improve the chances of the agent activating the correct topic.

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "BotPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860002, "cat_patternid": "bot-TriggerPhraseCount" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"6330666\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Functionality", "cat_patterncategory": 764860006, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-copilot-studio/guidance/trigger-phrases-best-practices#4", "cat_patterndetails": "Long Phrases", "cat_patterndetailsid": "04e503e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

", "cat_patterndescription": "

Avoid long trigger phrases. Trigger phrases exceeding 10 words in length can have negative impact on the topic recognition and the agent performance.

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "BotPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860002, "cat_patternid": "bot-LongPhrases" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978755\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Maintainability", "cat_patterncategory": 764860007, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-copilot-studio/guidance", "cat_patterndetails": "Condition Count", "cat_patterndetailsid": "07e503e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Consider breaking the topic into subtopics and redirect the conversation to those subtopics to improve maintainability and ensure good performance.

", "cat_patterndescription": "

Avoid large amount of conditions per topic. Large amount of conditions within single topic can have negative impact on the agent performance.

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "BotPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860002, "cat_patternid": "bot-ConditionCount" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978756\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": null, "cat_patterndetails": "Flow Count", "cat_patterndetailsid": "12e503e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Recommendation is to avoid slow logic in a flow and limit the number of flows per agent to 10 or less if possible, to ensure good end user performance.

", "cat_patterndescription": "

Avoid large amount of flows within an agent. Large amount of flows can increase latencies and have negative impact on the end user performance.

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "BotPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860002, "cat_patternid": "bot-FlowCount" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978757\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Security", "cat_patterncategory": 764860013, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-copilot-studio/guidance", "cat_patterndetails": "SharePoint Authentication Mode", "cat_patterndetailsid": "1be503e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "High", "cat_patternseverity": 764860003, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Ensure that authentication is enabled for agents using SharePoint sites as knowledge source.

", "cat_patterndescription": "

SharePoint sites cannot be used as knowledge source unless the agent requires/allows authentication.

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "BotPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860002, "cat_patternid": "bot-SharePointAuthMode" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978759\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Functionality", "cat_patterncategory": 764860006, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-copilot-studio/guidance", "cat_patterndetails": "Unused Topics", "cat_patterndetailsid": "29e503e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Unused topics clutter the user interface for the maker, and could be a source of confusion. Large amoungs of unused topics could have impact on agent performance. After reviewing them and confirming that they are in fact not in use, they should be removed.

", "cat_patterndescription": "

Topics that do not have trigger phrases and are not redirected to from other topics, are likely unused and could be removed.

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "BotPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860002, "cat_patternid": "bot-UnusedTopics" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978760\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Functionality", "cat_patterncategory": 764860006, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-copilot-studio/guidance", "cat_patterndetails": "Synonyms Quality", "cat_patterndetailsid": "2ae503e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Make sure to only enter keywords as synonyms. In most cases they should be single word in length.

", "cat_patterndescription": "

Synonyms should be keywords only, and entering longer phrases as synonyms should be avoided.

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "BotPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860002, "cat_patternid": "bot-SynonymsQuality" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"4978761\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Functionality", "cat_patterncategory": 764860006, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-copilot-studio/guidance", "cat_patterndetails": "Duplicate Regex Entities", "cat_patterndetailsid": "30e503e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec5b", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Regular expressions for entities should be unique within single agent. Having multiple entities with same pattern can be a source of confusion or conflict.

", "cat_patterndescription": "

Different entities should not have the same exact regular expression pattern.

", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "BotPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860002, "cat_patternid": "bot-DuplicateRegexEntities" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"6919954\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/canvas-apps/fast-app-page-load", "cat_patterndetails": "Cross screen dependencies", "cat_patterndetailsid": "5e492a87-9dff-ef11-bae2-00224824fa4d", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Medium", "cat_patternseverity": 764860002, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Keep cross screen dependencies between screens low. Use variable & collection rather than values from controls properties.
", "cat_patterndescription": "
Cross page references force the load of additional screens if one screen has a dependency on a control in a different screen.
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-InefficientDelayLoading" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"6919974\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Performance", "cat_patterncategory": 764860009, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/canvas-apps/add-images-pictures-audio-video", "cat_patterndetails": "Unused Media Resources", "cat_patterndetailsid": "509faeb7-a1ff-ef11-bae2-00224824fa4d", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
You can remove all unused media from the app to clean up or reduce the size of the app using Media > Remove unused media option.
", "cat_patterndescription": "
The app contains media (.jpg, .jpeg, .gif, .png, .bmp, .tif, .tiff, .svg, .wav, .mp3, .mp4) that have been uploaded to the app but not used in any screen.
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "app-UnusedMediaResources" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"6919989\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Usage", "cat_patterncategory": 764860015, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-copilot-studio/guidance", "cat_patterndetails": "End Of Conversation Usage", "cat_patterndetailsid": "a6464edc-a4ff-ef11-bae2-00224824fa4d", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "High", "cat_patternseverity": 764860003, "cat_patternrecommendation": "
Ensure you have an EndOfConversation topic with 'startBehavior: CancelOtherTopics'  and conversationOutcome: ResolvedImplied Or conversationOutcome: ResolvedConfirmed and it is referenced by at least one topic to properly end the conversation. Without this, no analytics is collected(no CSAT).
", "cat_patterndescription": "
Checks if there is at least one End Of Conversation topic (with CancelOtherTopics and a Resolved outcome), and at least one topic referencing it.
", "cat_patterntype@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "PowerAppsPattern", "cat_patterntype": 764860000, "cat_patternid": "bot-EndOfConversationReference" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"6330667\"", "cat_patterncategory@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Coding Standards", "cat_patterncategory": 764860001, "cat_patternscore@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "1", "cat_patternscore": 1, "cat_patterndoclink": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/guidance/coding-guidelines/use-data-operations#json-variables-vs-individual-variables", "cat_patterndetails": "Multiple Initialize Variable Actions", "cat_patterndetailsid": "04e503e3-a6f2-ef11-9341-000d3a4dec6a", "cat_patternseverity@OData.Community.Display.V1.FormattedValue": "Low", "cat_patternseverity": 764860001, "cat_patternrecommendation": "

Combine multiple 'InitializeVariable' actions into a single 'InitializeVariable' action of type object or use parallel initialization for faster execution.

", "cat_patterndescription": "

Check if 'Initialize Variable' actions are used more than once. Combine them into one action for efficiency or use parallel initialization for faster execution.
